description.text: A romantic couple seated in a swan-shaped boat gazing at each other while floating along a river with the Taj Mahal behind them. A full moon can be seen along with the reflection of the Taj in the river's waters. Mumtaz points to the water with her left hand as she holds a lute in her right. She is wearing a crown and shiny transparent clothes. Shah Jahan is wearing a turban and sitting behind Mumtaz.

description-en: A romantic couple seated in a swan-shaped boat gazing at each other while floating along a river with the Taj Mahal behind them. A full moon can be seen along with the reflection of the Taj in the river's waters. Mumtaz points to the water with her left hand as she holds a lute in her right. She is wearing a crown and shiny transparent clothes. Shah Jahan is wearing a turban and sitting behind Mumtaz. (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The picture of the Taj Mahal is regularly seen as a decorative element in either Muslim or Hindu households. The Taj Mahal can be called a national icon. (Catherine B. Asher) (gs)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: It was contructed by the mughal emperor, Shah Jahan in memory of his queen, Mumtaz Mahal. The Taj Mahal is the ultimate symbol of love. (gs)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: Taj Mahal features among seven wonders of the world and it is located at Agra, India. (AC)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The Taj Mahal is one of the most 'universal' symbols of (dramatic) sentimental/romantic love. See Kajri Jain's visual essay on Monuments, Landscapes and Romance (2009) where she writes: "(...) couples are consistently represented in and for the public: outdoors and frontally facing the viewer rather than or as well as each other, as is evident from the contortions in S. Courtallam’s calendar of Shah Jahan and Mumtaz Mahal with the monument to their love, the Taj Mahal, so that we are presented with a frontal, albeit upside-down, view of Mumtaz." (cited from "Monuments, Landscapes and Romance in Indian Popular Imagery", Kajri Jain, 2009, p.3.) She continues to refer the Taj Mahal to contemporary times: "Particularly in the last two images, the Taj as a classic monument of love and an icon of India presides over the participation of Indians in a modernity that packages together romance, tourism, consumerism and elements of westernisation, ..." (cited from "Monuments, Landscapes and Romance in Indian Popular Imagery", Kajri Jain, 2009, p.3.) (Kajri Jain) (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The Taj Mahal located in the Indian City Agra (Uttar Pradesh) is seen as a symbol for the love between the Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan and his Wife Mumtaz Mahal. The couple on the image is probably supposed to be the royal couple, but as Mumtaz Mahal was observing purdah (cover-up) all her life, her depiction on this poster must be imagination Shah Jahans devotion to Mumtaz Mahal was most likely genuine for she accompanied him on all his campaigns, and during and after their marriage he fathered no children other than hers. Mughal chronicles report at length on the emperor’s profound grief at her death. The saga of their love and the emperor’s despair over her death became legend. (Catherine B. Asher) (gs)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: Swans in Indian heritage are associated with female beauty, wisdom and wealth. (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The moonlit Taj Mahal is an image evoked in poetry, including that of the Nobel Prize winner Rabindranath Tagore (1861-1941) in which it is used to represent the sublime. (Catherine B. Asher) (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: It should be noted that the Taj Mahal was contructed after the death of Mumtaz Mahal (who is shown in this image) as her tomb. So, the possibility of Mumtaz and Shahjahan in such a romantic pose does not exist, and is only an imaginative scenario concieved by the artist. (ys)

related literature: Asher, Catherine B. 2010. Fantasizing the Mughals and Popular Perceptions of the Taj Mahal. Tasveer Ghar. http://www.tasveergharindia.net/cmsdesk/essay/114/index.html last accessed 2010-10-19 (gs)
related literature: Cyran, Eberhard (1993). Taj Mahal. Die Erinnerungen des Kaisers Sha Jahan." Heilbronn: Salzer. (gs)
related literature: Preston, Diana (2007). "A teardrop on the cheek of time. The story of the Taj Mahal". London: Doubleday. (gs)
related literature: Wayne E. Begley, “The Myth of the Taj Mahal and a New Theory of Its Symbolic Meaning,” Art Bulletin 61 (1979), 7-37. (gs)
related literature: Jain, Kajri (2009). "Monuments, Landscapes and Romance. Resisting the privacy of the couple". Tasveer Ghar. (sg)
related hyperlinks: http://tasveerghar.net/cmsdesk/essay/37/index_3.html, last accessed 2011-05-08, Tasveer Ghar essay (sg)
It was contructed by the mughal emperor, Shah Jahan in memory of his queen, Mumtaz Mahal. The Taj Mahal is the ultimate symbol of love.
Taj Mahal features among seven wonders of the world and it is located at Agra, India.

The Taj Mahal located in the Indian City Agra (Uttar Pradesh) is seen as a symbol for the love between the Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan and his Wife Mumtaz Mahal. The couple on the image is probably supposed to be the royal couple, but as Mumtaz Mahal was observing purdah (cover-up) all her life, her depiction on this poster must be imagination Shah Jahans devotion to Mumtaz Mahal was most likely genuine for she accompanied him on all his campaigns, and during and after their marriage he fathered no children other than hers. Mughal chronicles report at length on the emperor’s profound grief at her death. The saga of their love and the emperor’s despair over her death became legend.
Swans in Indian heritage are associated with female beauty, wisdom and wealth.
The picture of the Taj Mahal is regularly seen as a decorative element in either Muslim or Hindu households. The Taj Mahal can be called a national icon.

It should be noted that the Taj Mahal was contructed after the death of Mumtaz Mahal (who is shown in this image) as her tomb. So, the possibility of Mumtaz and Shahjahan in such a romantic pose does not exist, and is only an imaginative scenario concieved by the artist.

The Taj Mahal is one of the most 'universal' symbols of (dramatic) sentimental/romantic love. See Kajri Jain's visual essay on Monuments, Landscapes and Romance (2009) where she writes: "(...) couples are consistently represented in and for the public: outdoors and frontally facing the viewer rather than or as well as each other, as is evident from the contortions in S. Courtallam’s calendar of Shah Jahan and Mumtaz Mahal with the monument to their love, the Taj Mahal, so that we are presented with a frontal, albeit upside-down, view of Mumtaz." (cited from "Monuments, Landscapes and Romance in Indian Popular Imagery", Kajri Jain, 2009, p.3.) She continues to refer the Taj Mahal to contemporary times: "Particularly in the last two images, the Taj as a classic monument of love and an icon of India presides over the participation of Indians in a modernity that packages together romance, tourism, consumerism and elements of westernisation, ..." (cited from "Monuments, Landscapes and Romance in Indian Popular Imagery", Kajri Jain, 2009, p.3.)
The moonlit Taj Mahal is an image evoked in poetry, including that of the Nobel Prize winner Rabindranath Tagore (1861-1941) in which it is used to represent the sublime.
